docs.lead_paragraph: A garlicky sauce of hot and sweet peppers and tomatoes infuses the chicken in this fragrant dish.

headline.seo: Chicken and Pepper Stew — Recipes for Health

docs.snippet: A garlicky sauce of hot and sweet peppers and tomatoes infuses the chicken in this fragrant dish.

headline.main: A Life Saved by Screening (1 Letter)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Eugenides’s new novel, “The Marriage Plot,” has scenes describing yeast genetic studies that ring so true, many assume that researchers had to have given him some in-depth help.

headline.seo: Yeast Genetics in ‘The Marriage Plot’ - Scientist Was Fiction, but Not His Work
headline.main: The Scientist Was a Figment, but His Work Was Real
headline.print_headline: The Scientist Was a Figment, but His Work Was Real

docs.abstract: Researchers are astounded at the accuracy of scenes describing yeast genetic studies in Jeffrey Eugenides novel The Marriage Plot; author, who is not a scientist and has never been in a genetics lab, spent five years meticulously researching both the central topic and the lives of scientists in order to ensure an authentic text.
docs.snippet: Jeffrey Eugenides’s new novel, “The Marriage Plot,” has scenes describing yeast genetic studies that ring so true, many assume that researchers had to have given him some in-depth help.

docs.lead_paragraph: One pill of azithromycin was found to cure yaws, a disease that often brings painless skin sores but also sometimes swelling, pain ans disfiguration.

headline.seo: Azithromycin Is Found to Treat Yaws
headline.main: Yaws: New Treatment Found for Tropical Disease That Was Once Countered With Penicillin
headline.print_headline: Yaws: New Treatment Found for Tropical Disease That Was Once Countered With Penicillin

docs.abstract: Study published in journal The Lancet finds that one dose of azithromycin in pill form is as effective as a shot of penicillin at curing yaws, skin disease that has been reemerging in Africa, Southeast Asia and the Pacific Islands; Lancet editorial calls study the most important discovery in yaws research in 50 years.
docs.snippet: One pill of azithromycin was found to cure yaws, a disease that often brings painless skin sores but also sometimes swelling, pain ans disfiguration.

docs.lead_paragraph: Novelty-seeking, a personality trait long associated with trouble, turns out to be one of the crucial predictors of emotional and physical well-being.

headline.seo: Novelty-Seeking (Neophilia) Can Be a Predictor of Well-Being
headline.main: What’s New? Exuberance for Novelty Has Benefits
headline.print_headline: What’s New? A Penchant For Novelty Has Benefits

docs.abstract: Research is revealing that 'novelty-seeking,' a personality trait long associated with trouble, may actually be one of the crucial predictors of emotional and physical well-being when balanced with other stabilizing traits.
docs.snippet: Novelty-seeking, a personality trait long associated with trouble, turns out to be one of the crucial predictors of emotional and physical well-being.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study testing B vitamins and omega-3 fatty acids for cancer prevention has found no beneficial effect and — at least for women — some possibility of harm.

headline.seo: B Vitamins and Omega-3 Fatty Acids Don’t Help Prevent Cancer
headline.main: Regimens: No Cancer Benefits Seen in Supplements
headline.print_headline: Regimens: No Cancer Benefits Seen in Supplements

docs.abstract: Valentina A Andreeva study in The Archives of Internal Medicine finds that B vitamins and omega-3 fatty acids do not have a beneficial effect in preventing cancer, and may actually increase the rate of cancer in women.
docs.snippet: A new study testing B vitamins and omega-3 fatty acids for cancer prevention has found no beneficial effect and — at least for women — some possibility of harm.

docs.lead_paragraph: Therapy apps may soon make psychological help accessible in the grocery store line, on the bus, or just before a work presentation.

headline.seo: Feeling Anxious? Soon There Will Be an App for That
headline.main: The Therapist May See You Anytime, Anywhere
headline.print_headline: The Therapist May See You Anytime, Anywhere

docs.abstract: Researchers have been testing simple video-game-like programs aimed at relieving common problems like anxiety and depression, which may soon make psychological help accessible to many people anytime, anywhere; some critics warn that therapy depends strongly on human interaction, but several studies have shown that electronic therapies can yield practical results.
docs.snippet: Therapy apps may soon make psychological help accessible in the grocery store line, on the bus, or just before a work presentation.

docs.lead_paragraph: When explicitly offered a choice, more customers are likely to choose a smaller portion, researchers find.

headline.seo: Being Given Options Helps People Choose Smaller Portions, Study Finds
headline.main: Nutrition: Options Play a Role in Healthier Choices
headline.print_headline: Nutrition: Options Play a Role in Healthier Choices

docs.abstract: Dan Ariely study in journal Health Affairs finds that some 33 percent of customers at a restaurant chose to order less of a starchy side dish when smaller portion was offered; experiment seems to be more effective in deterring overeating than widely-used calorie labels.
docs.snippet: When explicitly offered a choice, more customers are likely to choose a smaller portion, researchers find.

docs.lead_paragraph: Canadian researchers found that transmission rates were linked to weather, but even more strongly to the closing of schools in the spring and their reopening in the fall.

headline.seo: Closing Schools May Help Control Flu Epidemics
headline.main: Prevention: Closing Schools to Control Flu Epidemics
headline.print_headline: Prevention: Closing Schools to Control Flu Epidemics

docs.abstract: David J D Earn study in journal Annals of Internal Medicine finds compelling evidence that closing schools is an effective way to control flu epidemics.
docs.snippet: Canadian researchers found that transmission rates were linked to weather, but even more strongly to the closing of schools in the spring and their reopening in the fall.

docs.lead_paragraph: “Health Care Reform,” by the economist Jonathan Gruber, offers an easy-to-understand walk through what has changed under the Affordable Care Act of 2010, and what it may mean in the future.

headline.seo: ‘Health Care Reform’ - Book Review - A Cartoon to Cut Through Red Tape
headline.main: A Cartoon That Cuts Through the Health Care Brambles
headline.print_headline: A Cartoon That Cuts Through the Health Care Brambles

docs.snippet: “Health Care Reform,” by the economist Jonathan Gruber, offers an easy-to-understand walk through what has changed under the Affordable Care Act of 2010, and what it may mean in the future.
